rows.title: The abundance and diversity of life in the soil depends on the amount of carbon (organic debris) available to the system
Plant debris and manure are the main sources of carbon in agricultural systems
keypoints_list: The main source of carbon getting into agricultural soils is plant/crop debris and livestock wastes.

rows.title: Residue additions are essential to create healthy soils
keypoints_list: A soil that receives regular addition of plant and animal residues, accumulates soil organic carbon.

rows.title: Soil physical property
image_title_list: Soil color- residue rich soils (left) residue deficient (right)
keypoints_list: Healthy soils are dark in color. The dark color indicates that the soil is rich in organic matter.

rows.title: Soil physical property
image_title_list: The white threads (below) are soil fungi that are binding the soil particles together and improving water infiltration and storage
keypoints_list: A soil that receives regular addition of residues is well aggregated.
Roots of crops, as well as the strands of fungi that decompose residues, together with other life in the soil, create channels in the soil and glue the soil particles loosely together.

Roots and water infiltrates easily.  
Pictures on right from the Cornell  soil health manual

rows.title: Loss of carbon from smallholder farms in western  Kenya
keypoints_list: Crop production is greatly reduced in low carbon soils
Low productivity leads to competing uses for biomass  (fodder, fuel….soils lose!)
This can quickly become a poverty trap for farmers who depend on ag for food and income!
Without residue addition, crop production exploits the When soils are degraded residue production & retention is problematic

Reduce plant to plant competition
keypoints_list: Oversowing reduces plant performance due to competition for nutrients, water and sunlight

rows.title: Reduce nutrient losses
keypoints_list: Cover compost and manure to protect land from the sun and rain, both of which cause nutrients, especially nitrogen to be lose

rows.title: Grow multipurpose legumes for N fixation
keypoints_list: Special bacteria that can make nitrogen make their home, called nodules, on the roots of legumes. Nitrogen is needed to make proteins in the bodies of living things. You can tell if these bacteria are actively making nitrogen in the nodules if they are pink on the inside.

Because certain legumes, like lablab, soya and groundnut, leave nitrogen in the soil where they grew, farmers can take advantage of this by rotating the legumes with cereals that have a high nitrogen demand

Farmers night paddocking system in western Zambia
keypoints_list: Traditional method for adding nutrients and water holding capacity to extremely sandy soils, which are otherwise poorly suited to cropping.
Youth build temporary paddocks on crop land and confine the animals there at night. Once the soil is covered with manure, they shift the paddock to fertilize the next patch.
